title: Amount of funding for projects in specific vulnerability areas of Germany
sections:
Amount of funding for projects in specific vulnerability areas of Germany

Distribution of adaptation research projects and the corresponding total amount of funding for three natural areas of Germany.

Note: as data about funding had to be retrieved manually for each single project, three indicative areas were selected and data were manually retrieved only for these areas.

Figure 2: Distribution of adaptation research projects and the corresponding amount of funding per natural area of Germany.

How to read the map

The map shows the number of adaptation projects, and the total amount of funds, for three specific natural areas in Germany.

Like in map 11c, the territory is not divided according to administrative regions, but to natural areas. Color represents the vulnerability level of each natural area.

For each of the three selected regions, the size of the circle represents the number of funded adaptation projects for that area (same as in map 11c), while the size of the triangle represents the total amount of  funding for those projects.

How the map is built (map building protocol)

As the information about funding was not available in the data base this had to be collected manually for most of the projects. Thus it was decided to do this only for selected regions: two highly vulnerable natural areas (Upper Rhine Rift and North-East German Lowland) are selected to analyse their funding situation, and in order to have a good comparison, an additional region with lower vulnerability (West German Lowland Bay) was chosen to collect funding data for (figure 2).

Funding data for the three selected natural areas manually collected for most of the projects by considering the following sources: Google (Web search), UFORDAT (German environment-related projects), Federal Government (BMBF, BMUB, other Federal Ministries), INTERREG (only projects with German participation), CORDIS (EU projects, 5th, 6th, 7th FP and others).

Projects can be related to more than one country, and to more than one natural area of Germany. In case a project is associated to more countries, we assumed an even division of funding among countries, so we divided the total amount of money by the number of countries involved. Then we did the same in the case of projects associated to more natural areas, dividing the resulting amount of funding allocated to Germany by the number of natural areas of Germany involved in the project.  

References

Zebisch, M., Grothmann, T., Schröter, D., Hasse, C., Fritsch, U., Cramer, W. (2005): Climate Change in Germany Vulnerability and Adaptation of climate sensitive sectors.” Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research. 2005. 1-205.
